awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Restoring Musculoskeletal Function by Designing Implantable Passive Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
1554739
Balasubramanian

This project designs miniature implantable mechanisms for attaching muscles to tendons and bone in orthopedic surgery.  The implants take the form of passive mechanisms, such as soft tendon networks, pulleys, and linkages. Instead of directly attaching muscles to tendons and bone using sutures, a surgeon can use the passive implants to re-route and re-arrange how a patient's tendons create movement at the joint.  By doing so, the implants enable increased force or range of motion at a joint using the patient's own muscles and without using any external power or electronics.  Overall, the implants enable new surgeries that provide the patient improved and customized manipulation and locomotion function when compared with the current suture-based surgical paradigm. In terms of impact, this project is expected improve quality of life for the disabled, seniors, and veterans, lead to new research in allied areas such as biomaterials and bioethics, and lead to new medical devices.

The research develops a framework for the design of such implantable mechanisms after quantifying the movement deficits that arise in the current suture-based surgical paradigm.  In particular, this project develops implants for two surgical applications: an implant that differentially distributes forces and movement from one muscle to multiple tendons for use in a hand surgery to restore grasping capability following median-ulnar nerve palsy; and an implant that scales up forces for use in a foot surgery to restore the collapsed foot arch.  The implants will be validated through biomechanical simulations, human and animal cadaver experiments, and live-animal experiments.  This project integrates this research with extensive educational activities.  Specifically, this project creates new curricula using hands-on open source hardware and software to train the next generation of leaders at the middle-school, high-school, undergraduate, graduate, and teacher levels in understanding the mechanics of human body movement and using robotics to improve human body movement.  The project also includes outreach programs to increase participation of women and under-represented minorities in the STEM fields within a culture of inclusivity and equality.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This NSF CAREER grant has laid a strong foundation for the research and development of two novel classes of miniature passive tendon-mounted implants for reconstructive surgeries. These implants, which are shaped as triangles and pulleys and integrate with the biological tendon(s), enable the surgical construction of mechanisms that enhance the functional attachment of the muscle to the tendon(s) and bone.  Two classes of implants are being developed: the FlexRite implant that distributes force and movement between one muscle tendon and two digital tendons to create differential action, and the AmpX implant that amplifies force and movement between one muscle tendon and one digital tendon.  This work has yielded the following outcomes, categorized as intellectual merit and broader impacts.

 

Intellectual merit

1.     Validated efficacy of the FlexRite through human cadaver, animal cadaver, and short-term live-animal implantation experiments.  The human cadaver experiment showed that FlexRite improves grip strength by 22%.

1.1.  Explored applications in hand surgery to restore whole-hand grasping function

1.2.  Developed and validated chicken and rabbit models

1.3.  Developed a method to understand how to customize implant geometry to achieve the desired biomechanical function

2.     Validated efficacy of AmpX through human cadaver, animal cadaver, and terminal animal experiments.  The terminal animal experiment showed that AmpX produced a force amplification of 1.39X.

2.1.  Explored applications in hand surgery to restore thumb lateral-pinch grasp and foot surgery to restore the foot arch.

2.2.  Developed and validated a rabbit model

2.3.  Developed a method to understand the variables in implant-based surgery to achieve the desired biomechanical function

2.4.  Measured friction between the tendon and the implant

2.5.  Showed for the first time how to amplify the force generated by a muscle using a passive pulley

3.     Created numerous novel benchtop testbeds for evaluating the implants in terms of measuring the following:

3.1.  Differential action (cadaver and live-animal study)

3.2.  Force amplification (cadaver and live-animal study)

3.3.  Mechanical security of FlexRite attached to tendons (mechanical testbed)

3.4.  Effect of abrasion on non-fouling coating applied to implant (mechanical testbed)

3.5.  Stress on surrounding tissues (mechanical testbed)

4.     Development of a tool to pick up, hold, and place a soft tendon at low-tension forces

5.     Developed insight into tendon biological response to mechanical loading

6.     Published seven journal papers

7.     Mentoring research community members

7.1.  Graduated three PhD students

7.2.  Graduated twelve Masters students

7.3.  Mentored over twenty undergrads in research projects

7.4.  Mentored one post-doctoral fellow

8.     Started a company (OrthoMechanica) to commercialize the implant technology.

9.     Published two patents.  Three more patents are under preparation.

 

Broader impacts

1.     Established an interdisciplinary group of researchers from engineering (robotics, mechanical engineering, biomaterials, and bioengineering), biomechanics, hand surgery, and veterinary medicine from multiple institutions (University of Washington, Oregon Health and Sciences University, University of Southern California, Stanford University, Cleveland Clinic, Washington University) and a Spinal Cord Injury Advocate (a tetraplegic veteran) to explore the domain of implantable mechanisms for reconstructive surgery.

2.     Mentored numerous graduate, undergraduate (NSF REU funded and otherwise), high-school, and middle-school research assistants and multiple projects in the domain of said implants.  The high-school students were hired through the Apprenticeships in Science and Engineering (ASE) program, and middle school students through the Summer Experience in Science and Engineering for Youth (SESEY) program.  These programs particularly encourage the involvement of women and under-represented minorities in research.  Graduate students mentored the junior students.  These students were also included in OSU’s “Robotics for the Real World” REU site’s mentoring program. The REU site mentored the students on research planning, presentation, and graduate school.

3.     Presented the work at numerous conferences, such as the annual meetings of the Military Health Systems Research Symposium and the Orthopedic Research Society and Tetrahand, and through invited talks at universities.

4.     Created and taught a new Honors College undergraduate course titled “Re-Engineering the Human Body using Robotics” in Winter 2022.

5.     Developed a Human Control Systems Curriculum that guides students in integrating robotics and biomechanics.  The kit includes open-source biomechanical simulation software (OpenSim) and a hardware kit that students can assemble to create an anthropomorphic robotic hand.

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2023
Modified by: Ravi Balasubramanian
